ticket.title: Numeric::Time is not consistent, giving confusing results to Duration#inspect
ticket.original-body:
Is there a reason that ActiveSupport::CoreExtensions::Numeric::Time#minutes (and hours) don't their own unit as a type when creating an ActiveSupport::Duration ?
@@@ ruby # for example def hours ActiveSupport::Duration.new(self * 3600, [[:seconds, self * 3600]]) end # could be def hours ActiveSupport::Duration.new(self * 1.hour, [[:hours, self]]) end @@@
The problem is that this creates confusing output for ActiveSupport::Duration#inspect
@@@ ruby # for example (1.month + 1.day + 5.minutes).inspect => "1 month, 1 day, and 300 seconds" @@@
I have included a patch with tests to show this example
I can write the fixes, I just want to know if there is a reason for what is there.
as a side note, I found this bug because I wanted to add functionality for outputting a number in seconds to a sentence.
I wrote this: http://gist.github.com/69934 which I was planning to add to ActiveSupport::Duration until I noticed #inspect. Another question is? does it make sense to use ActiveSupport::Duration#inspect for user output? should I add something like the method I wrote that can pull apart a number in seconds and still output a nice sentence (like: 65.seconds.inspect # => "1 minute and 5 seconds")?
ticket.latest-body:
Is there a reason that ActiveSupport::CoreExtensions::Numeric::Time#minutes (and hours) don't their own unit as a type when creating an ActiveSupport::Duration ?
@@@ ruby # for example def hours ActiveSupport::Duration.new(self * 3600, [[:seconds, self * 3600]]) end # could be def hours ActiveSupport::Duration.new(self * 1.hour, [[:hours, self]]) end @@@
The problem is that this creates confusing output for ActiveSupport::Duration#inspect
@@@ ruby # for example (1.month + 1.day + 5.minutes).inspect => "1 month, 1 day, and 300 seconds" @@@
I have included a patch with tests to show this example
I can write the fixes, I just want to know if there is a reason for what is there.
as a side note, I found this bug because I wanted to add functionality for outputting a number in seconds to a sentence.
I wrote this: http://gist.github.com/69934 which I was planning to add to ActiveSupport::Duration until I noticed #inspect. Another question is? does it make sense to use ActiveSupport::Duration#inspect for user output? should I add something like the method I wrote that can pull apart a number in seconds and still output a nice sentence (like: 65.seconds.inspect # => "1 minute and 5 seconds")?
ticket.original-body-html:
Is there a reason that ActiveSupport::CoreExtensions::Numeric::Time#minutes (and hours) don't their own unit as a type when creating an ActiveSupport::Duration ?


# for example
def hours
  ActiveSupport::Duration.new(self * 3600, [[:seconds, self * 3600]])
end
# could be
def hours
  ActiveSupport::Duration.new(self * 1.hour, [[:hours, self]])
end

The problem is that this creates confusing output for ActiveSupport::Duration#inspect


# for example
(1.month + 1.day + 5.minutes).inspect
=> "1 month, 1 day, and 300 seconds"

I have included a patch with tests to show this example

I can write the fixes, I just want to know if there is a reason for what is there.

as a side note, I found this bug because I wanted to add functionality for outputting a number in seconds to a sentence.

I wrote this: http://gist.github.com/69934 which I was planning to add to ActiveSupport::Duration until I noticed #inspect. Another question is? does it make sense to use ActiveSupport::Duration#inspect for user output? should I add something like the method I wrote that can pull apart a number in seconds and still output a nice sentence (like: 65.seconds.inspect # => "1 minute and 5 seconds")?

@@@ ruby # for example def hours ActiveSupport::Duration.new(self * 3600, [[:seconds, self * 3600]]) end # could be def hours ActiveSupport::Duration.new(self * 1.hour, [[:hours, self]]) end @@@
The problem is that this creates confusing output for ActiveSupport::Duration#inspect
@@@ ruby # for example (1.month + 1.day + 5.minutes).inspect => "1 month, 1 day, and 300 seconds" @@@
I have included a patch with tests to show this example
I can write the fixes, I just want to know if there is a reason for what is there.
as a side note, I found this bug because I wanted to add functionality for outputting a number in seconds to a sentence.

version.body-html:
Is there a reason that ActiveSupport::CoreExtensions::Numeric::Time#minutes (and hours) don't their own unit as a type when creating an ActiveSupport::Duration ?


# for example
def hours
  ActiveSupport::Duration.new(self * 3600, [[:seconds, self * 3600]])
end
# could be
def hours
  ActiveSupport::Duration.new(self * 1.hour, [[:hours, self]])
end

The problem is that this creates confusing output for ActiveSupport::Duration#inspect


# for example
(1.month + 1.day + 5.minutes).inspect
=> "1 month, 1 day, and 300 seconds"

I have included a patch with tests to show this example

version.title: Numeric::Time is not consistent giving confusing results to Duration#inspect

version.body:
another idea is to write a method in ActiveSupport::Duration that "normalizes" internal data.
@@@ ruby # example >> 65.seconds => 65 seconds >> 65.seconds.parts => [[:seconds, 65]] >> 65.seconds.normalize => 1 minute and 5 seconds >> 65.seconds.normalize.parts => [[:minutes, 1], [:seconds, 5]] @@@
any thoughts?
version.body-html:
another idea is to write a method in ActiveSupport::Duration that "normalizes" internal data.


# example
>> 65.seconds
=> 65 seconds
>> 65.seconds.parts
=> [[:seconds, 65]]
>> 65.seconds.normalize
=> 1 minute and 5 seconds
>> 65.seconds.normalize.parts
=> [[:minutes, 1], [:seconds, 5]]

any thoughts?
version.title: Numeric::Time is not consistent giving confusing results to Duration#inspect

version.diffable-attributes: --- :title: Numeric::Time is not consistent giving confusing results to Duration#inspect
version.title: Numeric::Time is not consistent, giving confusing results to Duration#inspect

version.body:
or, maybe this would be better
@@@ ruby >> 5.seconds + 1.minute => 65 seconds >> _.humanize => "1 minute and 5 seconds" @@@
I'm happy to implement any of the above, the only question is which.
version.body-html:
or, maybe this would be better


>> 5.seconds + 1.minute
=> 65 seconds
>> _.humanize
=> "1 minute and 5 seconds"

I'm happy to implement any of the above, the only question is which.
version.title: Numeric::Time is not consistent, giving confusing results to Duration#inspect

version.body:
I think the rationale is that days and months are not constant, their length depends on the context (1.month could stand for 30 or 31 days, a day might get an extra hour on DST)
Hours and minutes on the other hand have a constant length (1.hour is always exactly equal to 3600.seconds) so it makes sense to lump them together to make calculations faster and simpler.
version.body-html:
I think the rationale is that days and months are not constant, their length depends on the context (1.month could stand for 30 or 31 days, a day might get an extra hour on DST)

Hours and minutes on the other hand have a constant length (1.hour is always exactly equal to 3600.seconds) so it makes sense to lump them together to make calculations faster and simpler.
version.title: Numeric::Time is not consistent, giving confusing results to Duration#inspect

version.body: So, what would be the best action here? I'd love to contribute, and I think having a way to output a duration in human readable form would be a good feature.
version.body-html: So, what would be the best action here? I'd love to contribute, and I think having a way to output a duration in human readable form would be a good feature.
version.title: Numeric::Time is not consistent, giving confusing results to Duration#inspect

version.body: This supra footwear is called a modern vintage and has been since their introduction in 2003 where they began in Europe. Every supra shoes has some type of ornament, adornment or hardware and is comprised of aged leather that is bought from around the world. These supra uk are culturally engaging and allow for the woman wearing them to be enveloped in luxury.With new cuts and styles and hand stitched shoes, these timberland boots, heels or flats will make every foot look like it stepped out of vintage Hollywood. This timberland shoes have been worn and coveted by many of the most famous females in recent history. One such coach outlet, Jennifer Aniston, wears them in public and at home.This company makes many different unique styles of bags outlet from ankle booties to sandals, pumps, moncler jackets online, platforms and wedges. One louis vuitton bag in particular is ideal for the gothic style sense; it is patent leather and laces up the front of the shaft. There are also zippers on each side, and this shoe offers a flat heel of a half inch.Another great moncler jackets sale is featured in People's Style Watch and is called a platform bootie. This ture religion jeans has a raised panel in front of the ankle as well as a heel that measures 4.5 inches. The front offers a leather bandage appearance and is considered high fashion.
